turns.content: I need some help organizing my online shopping habits. I've been buying a lot of stuff online lately, at least 10 purchases in the past month, mostly from Amazon. Can you recommend any apps or tools that can help me track my spending?

The convenience of online shopping can indeed lead to a surge in purchases! Don't worry, I'm here to help you get a grip on your online shopping habits. Here are some excellent apps and tools that can help you track your spending:

1. **CamelCamelCamel** (Web, Chrome Extension): A price tracker specifically designed for Amazon purchases. It allows you to view price history, set price drop alerts, and even track your purchases.
2. **Rakuten (formerly known as Ebates)** (Web, Mobile App): A cashback and tracking platform that monitors your online purchases across various retailers, including Amazon. You'll earn cashback on eligible purchases, and the app will help you track your spending.
3. **Mint** (Web, Mobile App): A popular personal finance app that allows you to track your spending, create a budget, and set financial goals. It connects to your bank accounts and credit cards, so you can monitor your online purchases.
4. **Personal Capital** (Web, Mobile App): A financial management app that helps you track your income and expenses, including online purchases. It also offers investment tracking and financial planning tools.
5. **Digit** (Mobile App): A budgeting app that connects to your bank accounts and credit cards. It tracks your spending, including online purchases, and helps you save money by setting aside small amounts automatically.
6. **Amazon's Order History** (Web): If you primarily shop on Amazon, you can use their built-in order history feature to track your purchases. You can view your order history, including the date, item, and cost.
7. **Spent** (Mobile App): A simple, easy-to-use app that allows you to track your daily expenses, including online purchases. It categorizes your spending and provides insights to help you stay within your budget.
8. **Wally** (Mobile App): A budgeting app that connects to your bank accounts and credit cards. It tracks your spending, including online purchases, and offers personalized budgeting recommendations.
9. **Clarity Money** (Mobile App): A free app that connects to your bank accounts and credit cards, tracking your spending, including online purchases. It also offers budgeting tools and investment tracking.
10. **Spreadsheet or Budgeting Template**: If you prefer a more hands-on approach, you can create a spreadsheet or use a budgeting template (e.g., Google Sheets, Microsoft Excel) to track your online purchases manually.

Try out a few of these options to see which one works best for you. Remember to set up notifications and alerts to help you stay on top of your spending and make adjustments as needed.

I'll definitely check those out. One thing I'm worried about is that I tend to buy things on impulse, especially on weekends when I'm bored. Do you have any tips on how to avoid impulse buying online?

Impulse buying is a common challenge many of us face, especially when shopping online. Here are some tips to help you avoid impulse buying online:

1. **30-day rule**: When you see something you want to buy, wait 30 days before making the purchase. This helps you determine if the item is something you truly need or if the desire was just an impulsive want.
2. **Remove temptation**: Avoid browsing online shopping sites, especially on weekends when you're bored. Remove shopping apps from your phone's home screen, and log out of your accounts to make it harder to mindlessly shop.
3. **Use website blockers**: Tools like Freedom, SelfControl, or Cold Turkey can block access to shopping websites or entire sections of the internet during certain times of the day or for a set period.
4. **Use cashback and rewards strategically**: Instead of using cashback and rewards as an excuse to buy more, use them to make intentional purchases. Set a budget for the rewards you've accumulated and plan your purchases accordingly.
5. **Unsubscribe from promotional emails**: Reduce the temptation by unsubscribing from promotional emails and newsletters that often trigger impulse buying.
6. **Use the 10-minute rule**: When you see something you want to buy, wait 10 minutes before making the purchase. This short pause can help you reassess whether you really need the item.
7. **Ask yourself questions**: Before buying, ask yourself:
	* Do I really need this item?
	* Will it add value to my life?
	* Can I afford it?
	* Can I wait 30 days to buy it?
8. **Set a budget and track your spending**: Use one of the apps or tools I mentioned earlier to track your spending and stay within your budget. This will help you make more intentional purchasing decisions.
9. **Find alternative activities**: Replace online shopping with other hobbies or activities that bring you joy, such as reading, exercising, or spending time with friends and family.
10. **Practice mindfulness**: Be more mindful of your emotions and recognize when you're shopping out of boredom, stress, or other emotions. Take a step back, and address the underlying issue instead of turning to impulse buying.
11. **Use Amazon's 1-Click disable**: If you're an Amazon user, consider disabling the 1-Click ordering feature, which can make it too easy to make impulse purchases.
12. **Set up a "Wishlist"**: Instead of buying impulsively, add items to a wishlist and review it regularly to see if the item is still something you need or want.

Remember, breaking the habit of impulse buying takes time and practice. Be patient, and don't be too hard on yourself if you slip up. With time and persistence, you can develop healthier online shopping habits.

I like the 30-day rule idea. I'll definitely try that out. Also, I think I need to unsubscribe from those promotional emails. Do you have any tips on how to declutter my email inbox and make it more organized?

The 30-day rule is a great habit to develop!

Now, let's tackle that inbox of yours! Decluttering and organizing your email inbox can help reduce stress and save time. Here are some tips to help you get started:

1. **Unsubscribe from unwanted emails**:
	* Use services like Unroll.me or Bulk Unsubscribe to easily unsubscribe from multiple newsletters and promotional emails at once.
	* Look for the "Unsubscribe" link at the bottom of each email and click it to remove yourself from the list.
2. **Create filters and labels**:
	* Most email providers, like Gmail or Outlook, allow you to create filters and labels to categorize your emails.
	* Set up filters to automatically sort emails from specific senders or with certain keywords into designated labels or folders.
3. **Prioritize your inbox**:
	* Set up a "Priority" or "Important" label for emails that require immediate attention.
	* Use flags or stars to mark important emails that need follow-up.
4. **Use the 2-minute rule**:
	* If an email can be dealt with in less than 2 minutes, respond or take action immediately.
	* If it requires more time, schedule a task or add it to your to-do list.
5. **Implement the "Zero Inbox" policy**:
	* Aim to keep your inbox completely empty by regularly going through your emails and:
		+ Responding to or taking action on emails that require attention.
		+ Archiving or deleting emails that are no longer relevant.
		+ Scheduling tasks or reminders for emails that need follow-up.
6. **Schedule email checks**:
	* Set specific times of the day to check your email, rather than constantly throughout the day.
	* Use this time to batch process your emails, responding to multiple messages at once.
7. **Use email management tools**:
	* Consider using email clients like Sanebox, SaneBlackHole, or Boomerang to help manage your inbox.
	* These tools can help you prioritize emails, automate tasks, and even pause email notifications during certain times.
8. **Avoid email overload**:
	* Be cautious when signing up for newsletters or promotional emails.
	* Consider using a temporary email address or a disposable email service like 10 Minute Mail for one-time sign-ups.
9. **Regularly clean out your inbox**:
	* Set a reminder to regularly go through your inbox and clean out old, irrelevant emails.
	* Delete or archive emails that are no longer necessary.
10. **Take breaks from email**:
	* Consider implementing an "Email-Free Hour" or "Email-Free Day" to reduce email-related stress and increase productivity.

By implementing these tips, you'll be well on your way to a more organized and clutter-free inbox!

Remember, it might take some time to get your inbox organized, but the benefits will be worth it. You'll reduce stress, save time, and become more productive.
Can you tell me more about how I can use filters and labels to organize my inbox? I'm not really sure how to set them up.

Filters and labels are powerful tools to help you manage your inbox and reduce email overwhelm. I'd be happy to guide you through the process of setting them up.

**What are filters and labels?**

* **Filters**: Filters are rules that automatically sort, forward, or delete incoming emails based on specific criteria, such as sender, subject, or keywords.
* **Labels**: Labels are categories or tags that you can assign to emails to organize and group them. They help you quickly find and manage related emails.

**How to set up filters and labels in popular email providers:**

Here are step-by-step guides for setting up filters and labels in Gmail, Outlook, and Yahoo Mail:

### Gmail:

1. **Create a label**:
	* Log in to your Gmail account.
	* Click on the gear icon in the upper right corner and select "See all settings."
	* Go to the "Labels" tab.
	* Click on "New label" and enter a name for your label (e.g., "Shopping" or "Work").
	* Click "Create."
2. **Create a filter**:
	* Go to the "Filters and Blocked Addresses" tab.
	* Click on "Create a new filter."
	* Enter the filter criteria, such as the sender's email address or keywords in the subject or body.
	* Click "Create filter."
	* Select the label you created earlier from the "Apply the label" dropdown menu.
	* Choose any additional actions, such as "Skip the Inbox" or "Mark as read."
	* Click "Create filter."

### Outlook:

1. **Create a folder** (Outlook's equivalent of labels):
	* Log in to your Outlook account.
	* Right-click on the "Inbox" folder in the navigation pane.
	* Select "New Folder" and enter a name for your folder (e.g., "Shopping" or "Work").
	* Click "OK."
2. **Create a rule** (Outlook's equivalent of filters):
	* Go to the "File" menu and select "Manage Rules & Alerts."
	* Click on "New Rule."
	* Choose the condition for the rule, such as "Sender's address" or "Subject contains."
	* Select the action, such as "Move to folder" and choose the folder you created earlier.
	* Click "OK."

### Yahoo Mail:

1. **Create a folder**:
	* Log in to your Yahoo Mail account.
	* Click on the "Folders" tab.
	* Click on "New Folder" and enter a name for your folder (e.g., "Shopping" or "Work").
	* Click "Create."
2. **Create a filter**:
	* Go to the "Settings" icon (gear icon) in the upper right corner.
	* Select "More Settings."
	* Click on "Filters" from the left menu.
	* Click on "Add Filter."
	* Enter the filter criteria, such as the sender's email address or keywords in the subject or body.
	* Select the folder you created earlier as the "Move to" destination.
	* Click "Save."

**Tips and best practices:**

* Create labels or folders that make sense to you and your email habits.
* Set up filters to automatically sort emails from specific senders, such as newsletters or promotional emails.
* Use filters to prioritize emails from important senders, such as work colleagues or family members.
* Regularly review and update your filters and labels to ensure they're still relevant and effective.

By setting up filters and labels, you'll be able to:

* Reduce email clutter and overwhelm
* Quickly find and manage related emails
* Automate email organization and prioritization
* Save time and increase productivity

I hope this helps you get started with setting up filters and labels in your email provider!
